sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with no solutions.
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

2x + 3y = 7 
4x + 6y = 14 

Does this system of equations have a solution or not? If it has one, what is it? If it does not have a solution, explain why.
message_2:
This system of linear equations does not have a unique solution. The reason is that the second equation is just a multiple of the first equation. If we multiply the first equation by 2, we get:

(2x + 3y) * 2 = 7 * 2
4x + 6y = 14

Since the second equation is a multiple of the first equation, they are essentially the same line. In this case, the system of equations has infinitely many solutions, as any point on the line 2x + 3y = 7 will satisfy both equations.
